qas.question: In which language is the Quran recited?
What is the Arabic term for the cancellation of one part of the Quran by another?
What is the name of the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community's published Quran commentary?
In which language is the Tafseer e Kabir written?
What is the term for earlier portions of the Quran that may have been superseded by later parts?
In which language is the Quran unrecited?
In which language isn't the Quran recited?
What is the Arabic term for the continuation of one part of the Quran by another?
What is the name of the Ahmadiyya Jewish Community's published Quran commentary?
What is the term for later portions of the Quran that may have been superseded by earlier parts?

context: Because the Quran is spoken in <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>classical Arabic<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, many of the later converts to Islam (mostly non-Arabs) did not always understand the Quranic Arabic, they did not catch allusions that were clear to early Muslims fluent in Arabic and they were concerned with reconciling apparent conflict of themes in the Quran. Commentators erudite in Arabic explained the allusions, and perhaps most importantly, explained which Quranic verses had been revealed early in Muhammad's prophetic career, as being appropriate to the very earliest Muslim community, and which had been revealed later, canceling out or "abrogating" (<a1_0><b7_0>nāsikh<b7_0/><a1_0/>) the earlier text (<a4_0><b9_0>mansūkh<b9_0/><a4_0/>). Other scholars, however, maintain that no abrogation has taken place in the Quran. The Ahmadiyya Muslim Community has published a ten-volume <a3_0>Urdu<a3_0/> commentary on the Quran, with the name <a2_0><b8_0>Tafseer e Kabir<b8_0/><a2_0/>.
